title: Zechariah Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Zechariah chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Zechariah Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Zechariah Chapter 11.

questions.question: What did the LORD say to open in Zechariah 11:1?
options: Doors of Lebanon
Gates of Jerusalem
Heavens
Valley of Jehoshaphat
questions.correctAnswer: Doors of Lebanon
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:1 states, 'Open thy doors, O Lebanon, that the fire may devour thy cedars.'

questions.question: Who is told to 'howl' because the cedar is fallen, according to Zechariah 11:2?
options: Fir tree
Lions
Shepherds
Ravens
questions.correctAnswer: Fir tree
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:2 says, 'Howl, fir tree; for the cedar is fallen;...'

questions.question: What is the voice of the young lions described as in Zechariah 11:3?
options: Roaring
Whispering
Singing
Weeping
questions.correctAnswer: Roaring
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:3 says, 'a voice of the roaring of young lions; for the pride of Jordan is spoiled.'

questions.question: According to Zechariah 11:4, what is the shepherd commanded to do?
options: Feed the flock of the slaughter
Build a strong tower
Gather the harvest
Prepare the altar
questions.correctAnswer: Feed the flock of the slaughter
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:4 states, 'Thus saith the LORD my God; Feed the flock of the slaughter;'

questions.question: In Zechariah 11:5, what do the possessors do to the flock?
options: Slay them
Protect them
Feed them
Sell them to strangers
questions.correctAnswer: Slay them
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:5 says, 'Whose possessors slay them, and hold themselves not guilty...'

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 11:6 says God will no longer pity the inhabitants of the land.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:6 states, 'For I will no more pity the inhabitants of the land, saith the LORD.'

questions.question: What were the names of the two staves taken in Zechariah 11:7?
options: Beauty and Bands
Strength and Grace
Faith and Hope
Truth and Peace
questions.correctAnswer: Beauty and Bands
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:7 says, 'I took unto me two staves; the one I called Beauty, and the other I called Bands;'

questions.question: How many shepherds were cut off in one month according to Zechariah 11:8?
options: Three
One
Seven
Five
questions.correctAnswer: Three
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:8 states, 'Three shepherds also I cut off in one month;'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Zechariah 11:9: 'Then said I, I will not feed you: that that dieth, let it die; and that that is to be cut off, let it be cut off; and let the rest eat every one the flesh of ______.'
options: another
the enemy
the lion
the wolf
questions.correctAnswer: another
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:9 ends with 'let the rest eat every one the flesh of another.'

questions.question: What did Zechariah do to the staff called Beauty in Zechariah 11:10?
options: Cut it asunder
Polished it
Threw it away
Gave it to the people
questions.correctAnswer: Cut it asunder
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:10 says, 'And I took my staff, even Beauty, and cut it asunder,'

questions.question: How much was Zechariah's price weighed at according to Zechariah 11:12?
options: Thirty pieces of silver
Fifty pieces of gold
Ten talents of silver
One hundred shekels
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty pieces of silver
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:12 states, 'So they weighed for my price thirty pieces of silver.'

questions.question: True or False: The LORD instructed Zechariah to cast the thirty pieces of silver to the potter in the house of the LORD (Zechariah 11:13).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:13 states, 'Cast it unto the potter... And I took the thirty pieces of silver, and cast them to the potter in the house of the LORD.'

questions.question: What did Zechariah do to the staff called Bands in Zechariah 11:14?
options: Cut it asunder
Blessed it
Hid it
Sold it
questions.correctAnswer: Cut it asunder
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:14 says, 'Then I cut asunder mine other staff, even Bands,'

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 11:16 describes a shepherd who will heal the broken and feed the weak.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:16 says the shepherd 'shall not visit those that be cut off, neither shall seek the young one, nor heal that that is broken, nor feed that that standeth still.'

questions.question: According to Zechariah 11:17, what will happen to the idol shepherd's right eye?
options: Utterly darkened
Filled with tears
Covered with a bandage
Made bright
questions.correctAnswer: Utterly darkened
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:17 states, 'his right eye shall be utterly darkened.'

medium.title: Zechariah Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Zechariah Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 11:4-5 teach us about integrity and honesty in our work and leadership?
options: Leaders should exploit their people for personal gain
Shepherds should care for the flock and not sell them for profit
Possessors should ignore the suffering of their flock
It is acceptable to harm others if you do not feel guilty
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds should care for the flock and not sell them for profit
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:4-5 shows that God condemns those who slay the flock and are not guilty, and those who sell them for profit without pity. This teaches us that leaders must act with integrity and care for those they lead, reflecting honesty and responsibility.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with bitterness toward leaders who have failed them. Based on Zechariah 11:8-9, what biblical truth would you share about God's view on failed leadership?
options: God loves and supports failed leaders endlessly
Failed leaders will be cut off and God’s patience can end
God always forgives without consequences
Leaders never face judgment for their failures
questions.correctAnswer: Failed leaders will be cut off and God’s patience can end
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:8-9 describes how three shepherds were cut off in one month and God’s soul loathed them. This teaches that God holds leaders accountable and His patience has limits, encouraging believers to trust God's justice.

questions.question: What spiritual lesson about trust in God can be learned from Zechariah 11:10-11, where the staff called Beauty is broken?
options: Covenants with God are permanent and unbreakable
When God breaks a covenant, it signals a serious judgment
Trust should be placed in worldly leaders rather than God
Breaking a covenant is a sign of God's anger without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: When God breaks a covenant, it signals a serious judgment
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:10-11 shows the staff Beauty being broken to symbolize breaking the covenant God made with the people, indicating serious consequences. This teaches believers to trust God’s faithfulness but also His righteous judgment.

questions.question: How does the payment of thirty pieces of silver in Zechariah 11:12-13 highlight the importance of honesty and integrity in financial dealings?
options: Accepting bribes is justified if it makes one rich
A low payment for a valued servant is a symbol of betrayal
Money should be sought at any cost
Financial gain is always a blessing from God
questions.correctAnswer: A low payment for a valued servant is a symbol of betrayal
questions.explanation: In Zechariah 11:12-13, thirty pieces of silver was a low price for the shepherd, symbolizing betrayal and dishonesty. This teaches believers to practice honesty and avoid undervaluing others for personal gain.

questions.question: Based on Zechariah 11:14, what can believers learn about the importance of unity and reconciliation within the family and community?
options: Division between brothers is acceptable and expected
Breaking brotherhood leads to hardship and judgment
Ignoring family strife is the best approach
Unity is unimportant in spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking brotherhood leads to hardship and judgment
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:14 speaks of breaking the brotherhood between Judah and Israel, symbolizing division resulting in negative consequences. This teaches believers to pursue unity and reconciliation in families and communities.

questions.question: How does the description of the foolish shepherd in Zechariah 11:15-16 warn believers about leadership and responsibility?
options: A shepherd ignoring the weak and broken is harmful
Leaders should prioritize personal gain over the flock
It is acceptable to neglect the vulnerable
Shepherds should feed only the strong and ignore others
questions.correctAnswer: A shepherd ignoring the weak and broken is harmful
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:15-16 describes a shepherd who neglects the broken and weak, feeding on the fat and tearing claws. This warns believers that leaders must care for all, especially the vulnerable, showing responsibility and love.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged by leaders who fail to care for their congregations. According to Zechariah 11:6, what biblical truth about God's justice and timing would encourage them?
options: God will always deliver people from their enemies instantly
God will allow leaders and neighbors to bring consequences in His time
God ignores injustice and suffering
God delays judgment indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: God will allow leaders and neighbors to bring consequences in His time
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:6 states God will deliver men into their neighbors' and kings' hands to be smitten, and He will not deliver them out of their hands. This shows God’s timing in justice, encouraging trust and patience.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from Zechariah 11:12, where the shepherd asks for his price and receives thirty pieces of silver?
options: One should demand exorbitant payment for their service
Accepting a low price humbly can reflect reliance on God's plan
Monetary value defines a person's worth
Rejecting unfair payment is always wrong
questions.correctAnswer: Accepting a low price humbly can reflect reliance on God's plan
questions.explanation: In Zechariah 11:12, the shepherd accepts thirty pieces of silver, a low price, demonstrating humility and trust in God's sovereignty rather than human standards of value.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 11:1-3 use imagery to convey the consequences of unfaithfulness and disobedience in leadership?
options: The fire devouring Lebanon's cedars shows destruction following failure
The trees happily thrive regardless of leadership
The strong are always protected by good leaders
Leadership has no effect on the community
questions.correctAnswer: The fire devouring Lebanon's cedars shows destruction following failure
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 depict Lebanon's cedars and Bashan's oaks howling and falling, symbolizing ruin due to corrupt leadership. This teaches that unfaithfulness brings destructive consequences.

questions.question: True or False: According to Zechariah 11:17, God pronounces woe on the idol shepherd who abandons the flock.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:17 clearly states woe to the idol shepherd who leaves the flock, showing God's judgment on neglectful leaders.

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 11:7 teaches that God will feed and care for the poor and vulnerable flock even in times of judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 7 shows God feeding the poor of the flock, indicating His care for the humble and vulnerable even amid judgment, encouraging believers to trust His provision.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Zechariah 11:13, the thirty pieces of silver were cast to the ______, symbolizing the price of betrayal.
options: potter
altar
priest
temple
questions.correctAnswer: potter
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:13 specifically mentions casting the thirty pieces of silver to the potter in the house of the LORD, symbolizing the low price of betrayal and rejection.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 11:9 teach believers about the consequences of rejecting God's care and guidance?
options: Rejecting God's care leads to spiritual ruin and self-destruction
God will always force care upon those who reject it
Rejecting God has no real consequences
It is wise to refuse God's guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Rejecting God's care leads to spiritual ruin and self-destruction
questions.explanation: In verse 9, God refuses to feed those who reject Him, leading to death and self-consumption, teaching believers that rejecting God's care results in ruin.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and responsibility can be drawn from Zechariah 11:5, where shepherds show no pity for their flock?
options: Leaders must show compassion and stewardship over those entrusted to them
Shepherds are justified in neglecting their duties
Profit is more important than caring for others
Selfishness is accepted in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must show compassion and stewardship over those entrusted to them
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:5 condemns shepherds who sell the flock and pity them not, teaching believers the importance of compassionate stewardship and responsibility.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 11:16 warn believers about the dangers of selfish and harmful leadership within the church?
options: Selfish leaders harm the vulnerable and consume resources for themselves
Leaders should prioritize the weak over the strong
All leaders are equally good
Leadership has no effect on the spiritual health of the people
questions.correctAnswer: Selfish leaders harm the vulnerable and consume resources for themselves
questions.explanation: Verse 16 describes a shepherd who neglects the broken and feeds on the fat, tearing claws in pieces, symbolizing harmful, selfish leadership that damages the community.

hard.title: Zechariah Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Zechariah Chapter 11.

questions.question: What is the symbolic significance of the two staves named 'Beauty' and 'Bands' that the prophet takes in Zechariah 11?
options: They represent the covenant and unity between Israel and Judah
They symbolize the strength and power of Lebanon's cedars
They are signs of the shepherd's authority over the flock
They denote the division of the land into two kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the covenant and unity between Israel and Judah
questions.explanation: Verse 7 and 14 show that the staves 'Beauty' and 'Bands' symbolize the covenant ('Beauty') and the brotherhood ('Bands') which the prophet breaks, representing the division between Israel and Judah.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 11, what does the breaking of the staff called 'Beauty' signify?
options: The breaking of the covenant with all the people
The destruction of the cedar trees of Lebanon
The defeat of the mighty and the spoil of the proud
The silencing of the shepherds' voices
questions.correctAnswer: The breaking of the covenant with all the people
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:10 describes the breaking of the staff 'Beauty' as a sign that the prophet is breaking the covenant made with all the people.

questions.question: In Zechariah 11:12-13, the prophet is paid thirty pieces of silver. What is the significance of this amount?
options: It is considered a 'goodly price' and symbolizes betrayal
It is the price of a slave in the ancient Near East
It represents the cost of a flock of sheep
It is the ransom for a captive king
questions.correctAnswer: It is considered a 'goodly price' and symbolizes betrayal
questions.explanation: The thirty pieces of silver are the price paid to the prophet, which the LORD calls a 'goodly price' ironically, foreshadowing the betrayal of Jesus for the same amount in the New Testament (Zechariah 11:12-13).

questions.question: Which literary device is prominent in Zechariah 11:1-3, where Lebanon's doors are opened and cedars fall?
options: Personification of trees and nature
Alliteration in the description of the shepherds
Chiasm between Lebanon and Bashan
Typology of the shepherd as a king
questions.correctAnswer: Personification of trees and nature
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 personify trees like the cedars, firs, and oaks, using their fall and howling as symbols of judgment and loss, a common prophetic literary technique.

questions.question: Who are the 'shepherds' referred to in Zechariah 11:3-6, and what is their role in the prophecy?
options: Leaders of Israel who have failed their people
Foreign kings who will conquer the land
Priests who maintain the temple rituals
Prophets who announce God's judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders of Israel who have failed their people
questions.explanation: The 'shepherds' symbolize Israel's leaders who have been corrupted and caused the flock's suffering, as indicated by their being 'cut off' and the flock being delivered into enemies' hands (Zechariah 11:3-6, 8).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Feed the flock of the slaughter' (Zechariah 11:4) imply about the condition of Israel?
options: The people are destined for destruction under corrupt leadership
The flock is thriving under divine protection
The nation is united and prosperous
The enemies of Israel will be defeated
questions.correctAnswer: The people are destined for destruction under corrupt leadership
questions.explanation: The 'flock of the slaughter' suggests Israel is vulnerable and being led to destruction, reflecting the prophetic condemnation of the shepherds who fail to protect them (Zechariah 11:4).

questions.question: In Zechariah 11:6, to whom will the inhabitants of the land be delivered, according to the LORD?
options: Into the hand of their neighbour and king
Into the hands of the foreign invaders only
Into the care of faithful shepherds
Into the protection of the temple priests
questions.correctAnswer: Into the hand of their neighbour and king
questions.explanation: The LORD declares He will deliver the inhabitants into their neighbour's and king's hand, indicating internal strife and judgment from within the nation (Zechariah 11:6).

questions.question: True or False: Zechariah 11:8 states that the prophet cut off three shepherds in one month because he loved them deeply.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse says the prophet's soul loathed the three shepherds he cut off, and their souls abhorred him, indicating rejection and judgment, not love (Zechariah 11:8).

questions.question: What foreshadowing does the payment of thirty pieces of silver in Zechariah 11:12-13 have in the New Testament?
options: It foreshadows Judas Iscariot's betrayal of Jesus
It signifies the price of redemption through Christ
It predicts the destruction of the temple
It symbolizes the restoration of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Judas Iscariot's betrayal of Jesus
questions.explanation: The thirty pieces of silver are the exact amount Judas received for betraying Jesus, making this passage a prophetic foreshadowing (Zechariah 11:12-13; Matthew 26:15).

questions.question: What is the meaning of the term 'idol shepherd' in Zechariah 11:17?
options: A shepherd who abandons the flock and leads them astray
A faithful leader who protects the people
A foreign ruler who conquers Israel
A priest who serves false gods
questions.correctAnswer: A shepherd who abandons the flock and leads them astray
questions.explanation: The 'idol shepherd' is condemned for leaving the flock, with his arm and eye struck down, symbolizing the judgment on false leaders who neglect their duties (Zechariah 11:17).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Zechariah 11:16, the raised shepherd will not visit those that are ____, nor seek the young one nor heal the broken.
options: cut off
faithful
strong
poor
questions.correctAnswer: cut off
questions.explanation: The verse describes a shepherd who neglects those 'cut off,' highlighting the selfish and destructive leadership to come (Zechariah 11:16).

questions.question: What is the theological implication of the prophet telling the flock 'I will not feed you' in Zechariah 11:9?
options: God’s judgment includes withdrawal of care from the people
The flock will be miraculously sustained without a shepherd
The prophet is commissioning new shepherds
The people are entering a time of spiritual revival
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment includes withdrawal of care from the people
questions.explanation: The refusal to feed the flock signifies divine judgment by withdrawing protection and care, resulting in destruction and chaos (Zechariah 11:9).

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural context is reflected in the imagery of shepherds and flocks in Zechariah 11?
options: Shepherds as kings and leaders responsible for their people
Shepherds as mere herdsmen with no authority
Flocks as symbols of military armies
Trees as representations of foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds as kings and leaders responsible for their people
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern culture, shepherd imagery often symbolized kingship and leadership, which is used prophetically here to critique Israel’s rulers (Zechariah 11:4-8).

questions.question: How does the motif of 'shepherd' in Zechariah 11 relate to the broader biblical theme of leadership?
options: It critiques failed leadership and foreshadows the need for a righteous shepherd
It celebrates the ideal leadership of Israel’s kings
It focuses exclusively on literal shepherds rather than rulers
It emphasizes the independence of the flock from leaders
questions.correctAnswer: It critiques failed leadership and foreshadows the need for a righteous shepherd
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11 portrays faulty shepherds (leaders) leading to judgment, pointing toward the biblical hope for a perfect shepherd like the Messiah (Zechariah 11:15-17).

questions.question: Which New Testament figure is most closely connected to the prophetic imagery of Zechariah 11:12-13?
options: Jesus Christ
John the Baptist
King Herod
Paul the Apostle
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The payment of thirty pieces of silver and its rejection by the potter are cited in the New Testament as fulfilled in the betrayal and death of Jesus (Zechariah 11:12-13; Matthew 27:9-10).

theological.title: Zechariah Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Zechariah Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Zechariah 11:1, what is the symbolic significance of opening the doors of Lebanon for fire to devour its cedars?
options: Judgment upon a once majestic and strong nation
A call to celebrate the prosperity of Lebanon
An invitation to rebuild the cedars
A metaphor for spiritual revival
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment upon a once majestic and strong nation
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:1 symbolizes divine judgment upon Lebanon, whose cedars represent strength and majesty. This imagery aligns with other biblical passages like Isaiah 2:13 and Ezekiel 31:3-9, where cedars signify pride and strength that God will humble, illustrating God's sovereignty over nations.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 11:4, what is the LORD's command regarding the flock?
options: Feed the flock of the slaughter
Protect the flock from enemies
Lead the flock to green pastures
Gather the flock in peace
questions.correctAnswer: Feed the flock of the slaughter
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:4 commands feeding the 'flock of the slaughter,' indicating a divine appointment to shepherd a vulnerable group destined for judgment. This reflects themes in Ezekiel 34:2-6 and John 10:11, where shepherds are accountable for their flocks, and God judges unfaithful leaders.

questions.question: In Zechariah 11:7, the prophet takes two staves named 'Beauty' and 'Bands.' What do these staves symbolize?
options: God's covenant and unity between people
The strength of the nation and its wealth
The division between good and evil
The shepherd's power and authority
questions.correctAnswer: God's covenant and unity between people
questions.explanation: The staves 'Beauty' and 'Bands' in Zechariah 11:7 symbolize God's covenant ('Beauty') and the unity or bonds ('Bands') between Israel and Judah. This is supported by 2 Corinthians 3:6 (new covenant), Ezekiel 37:15-19 (unity of Israel), and Psalm 89:34 (God's covenant faithfulness).

questions.question: What does the breaking of the staff 'Beauty' in Zechariah 11:10 signify?
options: The breaking of God's covenant with the people
The destruction of the physical land
The end of the priestly lineage
The punishment of foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: The breaking of God's covenant with the people
questions.explanation: The staff 'Beauty' represents God's covenant, and its breaking in Zechariah 11:10 symbolizes the rupture of that covenant due to Israel's unfaithfulness. This theme is reflected in Jeremiah 31:31-32 (new covenant after old is broken) and Hebrews 8:7, highlighting covenantal faithfulness and judgment.

questions.question: How much was the prophet's price in Zechariah 11:12, and what is its significance?
options: Thirty pieces of silver, symbolizing betrayal and rejection
Fifty pieces of gold, symbolizing wealth and honor
Seventy pieces of silver, symbolizing ransom
Ten pieces of silver, symbolizing humble service
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty pieces of silver, symbolizing betrayal and rejection
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:12 states the price as thirty pieces of silver, a sum associated with betrayal, notably the price paid to Judas for Jesus (Matthew 26:15), emphasizing rejection of God's servant. This price is echoed in Exodus 21:32 (price for a slave), illustrating devaluation of the prophet and Messiah.

questions.question: What action does the LORD command regarding the thirty pieces of silver in Zechariah 11:13?
options: Cast it to the potter in the house of the LORD
Use it to redeem the land
Give it to the poor
Keep it as a treasure
questions.correctAnswer: Cast it to the potter in the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:13 directs casting the thirty pieces of silver to the potter, symbolizing the contempt for the price and the rejected servant. This act reflects the imagery in Jeremiah 18:2-6 (potter shaping clay) and Matthew 27:7, where the silver is thrown into the temple, highlighting divine judgment.

questions.question: What is the significance of breaking the staff 'Bands' in Zechariah 11:14?
options: Breaking the brotherhood between Judah and Israel
Ending the covenant with the Gentiles
Symbolizing the destruction of the temple
Signifying the breaking of the law
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking the brotherhood between Judah and Israel
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:14 shows the breaking of 'Bands' as the severing of unity between Judah and Israel, symbolizing division among God's people. This is consistent with 1 Kings 12:16-20 and Ezekiel 37:16-17, where two sticks represent divided kingdoms until God reunites them.

questions.question: According to Zechariah 11:16, what characterizes the 'foolish shepherd' raised up by the LORD?
options: He neglects the weak and consumes the fat
He protects and heals the flock
He leads the flock to rest
He sacrifices himself for the sheep
questions.correctAnswer: He neglects the weak and consumes the fat
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:16 describes the foolish shepherd as one who neglects the broken and young while preying on the strong ('eats the flesh of the fat'). This contrasts with the good shepherd motif in John 10:11 and Ezekiel 34:11-16, revealing a corrupted leadership that fails God's covenant purpose.

questions.question: What is the prophetic consequence for the 'idol shepherd' in Zechariah 11:17?
options: His arm will be dried up and his right eye darkened
He will be exalted among the nations
He will lead the flock to abundance
He will receive divine blessing
questions.correctAnswer: His arm will be dried up and his right eye darkened
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:17 pronounces woe on the idol shepherd, cursing his arm and eye to symbolize loss of strength and insight due to unfaithfulness. This judgment aligns with Isaiah 59:10 and Ezekiel 34:18, where God punishes bad shepherds for neglecting His people.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Feed the flock of the slaughter' in Zechariah 11:4 imply about the condition of the people?
options: They are destined for destruction due to unfaithfulness
They are being prepared for a peaceful restoration
They are protected by strong leadership
They are spiritually flourishing
questions.correctAnswer: They are destined for destruction due to unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: The phrase in Zechariah 11:4 indicates the people are like sheep about to be slaughtered, reflecting judgment due to sinfulness. This theme is echoed in Psalm 44:22 and Isaiah 53:7, where the suffering of God's people is linked to divine discipline and eventual redemption.

questions.question: How does Zechariah 11:6 describe God's attitude towards the inhabitants of the land?
options: God will no longer pity them and will deliver them to their enemies
God will protect and bless them abundantly
God will restore them swiftly
God will send prophets to guide them
questions.correctAnswer: God will no longer pity them and will deliver them to their enemies
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:6 reveals God's withdrawal of pity, allowing the inhabitants to be handed over to their neighbors and kings as judgment. This reflects divine justice found in Deuteronomy 28:25 and Hosea 4:6, where rejection leads to exile and oppression.

questions.question: What does Zechariah 11:8 indicate about the prophet’s relationship with the three shepherds he cut off?
options: He loathed them, and they abhorred him
He loved them despite their faults
He was indifferent towards them
He sought to reconcile with them
questions.correctAnswer: He loathed them, and they abhorred him
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11:8 states mutual loathing between the prophet and the three shepherds, symbolizing deep conflict and rejection of corrupt leaders. This mirrors Proverbs 6:16-19 and Ezekiel 34:2-10, where false shepherds are condemned for harming the flock.

questions.question: What does the prophet declare in Zechariah 11:9 about feeding the flock after cutting off the three shepherds?
options: He will not feed them; let the weak perish
He will nourish all with care
He will appoint new shepherds
He will lead them to safety
questions.correctAnswer: He will not feed them; let the weak perish
questions.explanation: In Zechariah 11:9, the prophet refuses to feed the flock, allowing the weak to die, symbolizing God's judgment on a rebellious people. This harsh stance aligns with Ezekiel 34:4 and Matthew 25:32-33, where unfaithful leadership leads to divine discipline.

questions.question: What does the 'price' given to the prophet in Zechariah 11:12 reveal about the people's valuation of God's servant?
options: They undervalue and reject him
They honor him generously
They acknowledge his divine authority
They seek to protect him
questions.correctAnswer: They undervalue and reject him
questions.explanation: The thirty pieces of silver paid in Zechariah 11:12 demonstrate the people's disdain and rejection of God's servant, paralleling Judas' betrayal in Matthew 26:14-16. This illustrates the biblical theme of the Messiah being despised (Isaiah 53:3).

questions.question: What theological theme is illustrated by the imagery of the 'flock' and 'shepherds' throughout Zechariah 11?
options: God's judgment on corrupt leadership and covenant unfaithfulness
The prosperity of Israel under faithful rulers
The unity of the church in Christ
The promise of universal peace
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment on corrupt leadership and covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Zechariah 11 uses shepherd and flock imagery (verses 3-4, 7, 16-17) to emphasize the failure of Israel's leaders and the consequent divine judgment. This theme is consistent with Ezekiel 34, Psalm 23, and John 10, where God holds leaders accountable and promises ultimate restoration.
